_88vtep.description: Midonet representation of a VXLAN Tunnel EndPoint, or VTEP, which allows you to merge a Midonet L2 network with physical L2 network over an IP tunnel. Once you create the Midonet VTEP representation of your external VTEP, you can bind Neutron networks to the VTEP's ports.  All properties other than those required in POST are obtained from the external VTEP configuration and not controlled by Midonet.

_88neutron_network.description: If a network is created and marked as external, MidoNet API also creates an administratively owned router called Provider Router. Provider router is a MidoNet virtual router that serves as the gateway router for the OpenStack Neutron deployment. This router is responsible for forwarding traffic between the Internet and the OpenStack cloud. It is up to the network operator to configure this router. There can be at most one instance of provider router at any time. To locate this router, search for the router with the name 'MidoNet Provider Router'.

_88rule.description: Rule is an entity that represents a rule on a virtual router chain in MidoNet.  ### How L2 Address masking works  dlDstMask and dlSrcMask help reduce the number of L2 address match rules.  For example, if you specify dlDstMask to be 'ffff.0000.0000', and if dlDst is 'abcd.0000.0000', all traffic with the destination MAC address that starts with 'abcd' will be matched.
_88rule.title: Rule

$eref.description: A unique identifier of the resource.

___nwDstAddress.description: The address part of the IP destination prefix to match.

___dlType.description: Set the data link layer type (ethertype) of packets matched by this rule. The type provided is not check for validity.

___invNwSrc.description: Invert the IP source prefix predicate. Match packets whose source is NOT in the prefix.

___type.description: Must be one of these strings: "accept", "dnat", "drop", "jump", "rev_dnat", "rev_snat", "reject", "return", "snat".

___invInPorts.description: Inverts the in_ports predicate. Match if the packet's ingress is NOT in in_ports.

___uri.description: A GET against this URI refreshes the representation of this resource.

___jumpChainId.description: ID of the jump chain. If the type == jump then this field is required.

___invTpDst.description: Invert the destination TCP/UDP port range predicate. Match packets whose dest port is NOT in the range.

___flowAction.description: Action to take on each flow. If the type is snat, dnat, rev_snat and rev_dnat then this field is required. Must be one of accept, continue, return.

___outPorts.description: The list of (interior or exterior) egress port UUIDs to match.

___nwProto.description: The value of the IP packet TOS field to match (0-255).

___nwTos.description: The value of the IP packet TOS field to match (0-255).

___dlSrc.description: The data link layer source that this rule matches on. A MAC address in the form aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff.

___invOutPorts.description: Inverts the out_ports predicate. Match if the packet's egress is NOT in out_ports.

___invDlSrc.description: Set whether the match on the data link layer source should be inverted (match packets whose data layer link source is NOT equal to dlSrc). Will be stored, but ignored until dlSrc is set.

___condInvert.description: Invert the conjunction of all the other predicates.

___natTargets.description: The list of nat targets. Each nat target should be an JSON object that contains the following fields:    * addressFrom: The first IP address in the range of IP addresses used as                  NAT targets   * addressTo: The last IP address in the range of IP addresses used as                NAT targets   * portFrom: The first port number in the range of port numbers used as               NAT targets   * portTo: The last port number in the range of port numbers used as NAT             targets  For an example: {"addressFrom": "1.2.3.4", "addressTo": "5.6.7.8", "portFrom": "22", "portTo": "80"}. This field is required if the type is dnat or snat.

$eref.description: A range which has the start value and the end value.

___tpSrc.description: A JSON representation of the Range object representing the tcp/udp source port range to match, like {"start":80,"end":400}. When creating an ICMP rule, this field should be set to the ICMP type value. The absence of a Range will be interpreted as "any".

___invNwDst.description: Invert the IP dest prefix predicate. Match packets whose destination is NOT in the prefix.

___dlSrcMask.description: Source MAC address mask in the format xxxx.xxxx.xxxx where each x is a hexadecimal digit.

___chainId.description: ID of the chain that this chain belongs to.

___invNwProto.description: Invert the nwProto predicate. Match if the packet's protocol number is not nwProto.

___portGroup.description: ID of the port group that you want to filter traffic from. If matched, the filter action is applied to any packet coming from ports belonging to the specified port group.

___invTpSrc.description: Invert the source TCP/UDP port range predicate. Match packets whose source port is NOT in the range.

___fragmentPolicy.description: The policy for fragmented packet handling. The accepted values are:    * "any": matches on all packets, including fragments.   * "header": matches on header fragment packet   * "nonheader": matches on fragmented non-header packets   * "unfragmented": matches only on unfragmented packets  If L4 fields are specified (tpSrc or tpDst) then only "header" and "unfragmented" are allowed, and "header" is the default. If L4 fields are not specified, "any" is the default.

___dlDst.description: The data link layer destination that this rule matches on. A MAC address in the form aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff.

___invDlDst.description: Set whether the match on the data link layer destination should be inverted (match packets whose data link layer destination is NOT equal to dlDst). Will be stored, but ignored until dlDst is set.

___nwSrcAddress.description: The length of the source IP prefix to match (number of fixed network bits).

___invDlType.description: Set whether the match on the data link layer type should be inverted (match packets whose data link layer type is NOT equal to the Ethertype set by dlType. Will be stored, but ignored until dlType is set.

___nwSrcLength.description: The length of the source IP prefix to match (number of fixed network bits).

$eref.description: A range which has the start value and the end value.

___tpDst.description: A JSON representation of the Range object representing the tcp/udp destination port range to match, like {"start":80,"end":400}. When creating an ICMP rule, this field should be set to the ICMP code value. A null value in this field will be interpreted as "any".

___inPorts.description: The list of (interior or exterior) ingress port UUIDs to match.

___id.description: A unique identifier of the resource.

___position.description: The position at which this rule should be inserted >= 1 and <= the greatest position in the chain + 1. If not specified, it is assumed to be 1.

___nwDstLength.description: The length of the IP destination prefix to match.

_88system_state.description: System State specifies parameters for the various states the deployment might be in. You may modify the system state to make limited changes to the behavior of midonet. For example, changing the "state" field to "UPGRADE" will cause the spawning of new midolman agents to abort.
_88system_state.title: System State

___availability.description: Setting the availability to "READONLY" will cause most API requests to be rejected. The exceptions are only administrative APIs that don't affect the topology: system_state and write_version. This is meant to let the operator stop REST API requests while performing maintenance or upgrades. Setting the availability to "READWRITE" (the default value) allows both GETs and PUT/POST API requests.

___state.description: Setting the state field to "UPGRADE" will put the midolman into "upgrade mode", which will cause all new midolman agents starting up in the deployment to abort the start up process. This is used during deployment wide upgrades to prevent unexpected startups of any midolman agent that might have the wrong version. This state can be reversed by setting the upgrade field to "ACTIVE". The deployment is not in upgrade state by default.

$eref.description: A unique identifier of the resource.

___link.description: Location of the port link resource. A POST against this URI links two interior ports. In the body of the request, 'peerId' must be specified to indicate the peer interior port ID. A DELETE against this URI removes the link.

___vifId.description: ID of the VIF plugged into the port.

___type.description: Type of device port. It must be one of:    * Router   * Bridge  A new router or bridge port is unplugged. Depending on what it is later attached to, it is referred to as an exterior or interior port.  An exterior router port is a virtual port that plugs into the VIF of an entity, such as a VM. It can also be a virtual port connected to a host physical port, directly or after implementing tunnel encapsulation. Access to exterior ports is managed by OpenVSwitch (OpenFlow switch). Exterior bridge port is the same as exterior router port but it is a port on a virtual bridge. Upon being bound to an interface, the port becomes exterior and will have the hostId, host, and interfaceName fields be non-null. The peer and peerId fields will be null.  An interior router port is a virtual port that only exists in the MidoNet virtual router network abstraction. It refers to a logical connection to another virtual networking device such as another router. An interior bridge port is the equivalent on a virtual bridge. Upon being linked to a peer, a port will become interior and will have the peer and peerId fields be non-null. The hostId, host, and interfaceName fields will be null.  There is a third type of port, Vxlan, which is created automatically when binding a VTEP to a Neutron network. The only operations supported on a port of this type are GET and DELETE. Deleting a VXLAN port will delete all associated VTEP bindings.

$eref.description: System State specifies parameters for the various states the deployment might be in. You may modify the system state to make limited changes to the behavior of midonet. For example, changing the "state" field to "UPGRADE" will cause the spawning of new midolman agents to abort.
$eref.title: System State

___availability.description: Setting the availability to "READONLY" will cause most API requests to be rejected. The exceptions are only administrative APIs that don't affect the topology: system_state and write_version. This is meant to let the operator stop REST API requests while performing maintenance or upgrades. Setting the availability to "READWRITE" (the default value) allows both GETs and PUT/POST API requests.

___state.description: Setting the state field to "UPGRADE" will put the midolman into "upgrade mode", which will cause all new midolman agents starting up in the deployment to abort the start up process. This is used during deployment wide upgrades to prevent unexpected startups of any midolman agent that might have the wrong version. This state can be reversed by setting the upgrade field to "ACTIVE". The deployment is not in upgrade state by default.

$eref.description: Rule is an entity that represents a rule on a virtual router chain in MidoNet.  ### How L2 Address masking works  dlDstMask and dlSrcMask help reduce the number of L2 address match rules.  For example, if you specify dlDstMask to be 'ffff.0000.0000', and if dlDst is 'abcd.0000.0000', all traffic with the destination MAC address that starts with 'abcd' will be matched.
$eref.title: Rule

___nwDstAddress.description: The address part of the IP destination prefix to match.

___dlType.description: Set the data link layer type (ethertype) of packets matched by this rule. The type provided is not check for validity.

___invNwSrc.description: Invert the IP source prefix predicate. Match packets whose source is NOT in the prefix.

___type.description: Must be one of these strings: "accept", "dnat", "drop", "jump", "rev_dnat", "rev_snat", "reject", "return", "snat".

___invInPorts.description: Inverts the in_ports predicate. Match if the packet's ingress is NOT in in_ports.

___uri.description: A GET against this URI refreshes the representation of this resource.

___jumpChainId.description: ID of the jump chain. If the type == jump then this field is required.

___invTpDst.description: Invert the destination TCP/UDP port range predicate. Match packets whose dest port is NOT in the range.

___flowAction.description: Action to take on each flow. If the type is snat, dnat, rev_snat and rev_dnat then this field is required. Must be one of accept, continue, return.

___outPorts.description: The list of (interior or exterior) egress port UUIDs to match.

___nwProto.description: The value of the IP packet TOS field to match (0-255).

___nwTos.description: The value of the IP packet TOS field to match (0-255).

___dlSrc.description: The data link layer source that this rule matches on. A MAC address in the form aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff.

___invOutPorts.description: Inverts the out_ports predicate. Match if the packet's egress is NOT in out_ports.

___invDlSrc.description: Set whether the match on the data link layer source should be inverted (match packets whose data layer link source is NOT equal to dlSrc). Will be stored, but ignored until dlSrc is set.

___condInvert.description: Invert the conjunction of all the other predicates.

___natTargets.description: The list of nat targets. Each nat target should be an JSON object that contains the following fields:    * addressFrom: The first IP address in the range of IP addresses used as                  NAT targets   * addressTo: The last IP address in the range of IP addresses used as                NAT targets   * portFrom: The first port number in the range of port numbers used as               NAT targets   * portTo: The last port number in the range of port numbers used as NAT             targets  For an example: {"addressFrom": "1.2.3.4", "addressTo": "5.6.7.8", "portFrom": "22", "portTo": "80"}. This field is required if the type is dnat or snat.

___tpSrc.description: A JSON representation of the Range object representing the tcp/udp source port range to match, like {"start":80,"end":400}. When creating an ICMP rule, this field should be set to the ICMP type value. The absence of a Range will be interpreted as "any".

___invNwDst.description: Invert the IP dest prefix predicate. Match packets whose destination is NOT in the prefix.

___dlSrcMask.description: Source MAC address mask in the format xxxx.xxxx.xxxx where each x is a hexadecimal digit.

___chainId.description: ID of the chain that this chain belongs to.

___invNwProto.description: Invert the nwProto predicate. Match if the packet's protocol number is not nwProto.

___portGroup.description: ID of the port group that you want to filter traffic from. If matched, the filter action is applied to any packet coming from ports belonging to the specified port group.

___invTpSrc.description: Invert the source TCP/UDP port range predicate. Match packets whose source port is NOT in the range.

___fragmentPolicy.description: The policy for fragmented packet handling. The accepted values are:    * "any": matches on all packets, including fragments.   * "header": matches on header fragment packet   * "nonheader": matches on fragmented non-header packets   * "unfragmented": matches only on unfragmented packets  If L4 fields are specified (tpSrc or tpDst) then only "header" and "unfragmented" are allowed, and "header" is the default. If L4 fields are not specified, "any" is the default.

___dlDst.description: The data link layer destination that this rule matches on. A MAC address in the form aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff.

___invDlDst.description: Set whether the match on the data link layer destination should be inverted (match packets whose data link layer destination is NOT equal to dlDst). Will be stored, but ignored until dlDst is set.

___nwSrcAddress.description: The length of the source IP prefix to match (number of fixed network bits).

___invDlType.description: Set whether the match on the data link layer type should be inverted (match packets whose data link layer type is NOT equal to the Ethertype set by dlType. Will be stored, but ignored until dlType is set.

___nwSrcLength.description: The length of the source IP prefix to match (number of fixed network bits).

___tpDst.description: A JSON representation of the Range object representing the tcp/udp destination port range to match, like {"start":80,"end":400}. When creating an ICMP rule, this field should be set to the ICMP code value. A null value in this field will be interpreted as "any".

___inPorts.description: The list of (interior or exterior) ingress port UUIDs to match.

___id.description: A unique identifier of the resource.

___position.description: The position at which this rule should be inserted >= 1 and <= the greatest position in the chain + 1. If not specified, it is assumed to be 1.

___nwDstLength.description: The length of the IP destination prefix to match.

$eref.description: If a network is created and marked as external, MidoNet API also creates an administratively owned router called Provider Router. Provider router is a MidoNet virtual router that serves as the gateway router for the OpenStack Neutron deployment. This router is responsible for forwarding traffic between the Internet and the OpenStack cloud. It is up to the network operator to configure this router. There can be at most one instance of provider router at any time. To locate this router, search for the router with the name 'MidoNet Provider Router'.

___link.description: Location of the port link resource. A POST against this URI links two interior ports. In the body of the request, 'peerId' must be specified to indicate the peer interior port ID. A DELETE against this URI removes the link.

___vifId.description: ID of the VIF plugged into the port.

___type.description: Type of device port. It must be one of:    * Router   * Bridge  A new router or bridge port is unplugged. Depending on what it is later attached to, it is referred to as an exterior or interior port.  An exterior router port is a virtual port that plugs into the VIF of an entity, such as a VM. It can also be a virtual port connected to a host physical port, directly or after implementing tunnel encapsulation. Access to exterior ports is managed by OpenVSwitch (OpenFlow switch). Exterior bridge port is the same as exterior router port but it is a port on a virtual bridge. Upon being bound to an interface, the port becomes exterior and will have the hostId, host, and interfaceName fields be non-null. The peer and peerId fields will be null.  An interior router port is a virtual port that only exists in the MidoNet virtual router network abstraction. It refers to a logical connection to another virtual networking device such as another router. An interior bridge port is the equivalent on a virtual bridge. Upon being linked to a peer, a port will become interior and will have the peer and peerId fields be non-null. The hostId, host, and interfaceName fields will be null.  There is a third type of port, Vxlan, which is created automatically when binding a VTEP to a Neutron network. The only operations supported on a port of this type are GET and DELETE. Deleting a VXLAN port will delete all associated VTEP bindings.

___portGroups.description: A GET against this URI retrieves the port groups that this port is a member of.

___networkAddress.description: IP address of the network attached to this port. For example, 192.168.10.32.

___adminStateUp.description: The administrative state of the port. If false (down), the port stops forwarding packets. If it is a router port, it adittionally replies with a  'Communication administratively prohibited' ICMP Default is true (up).

___uri.description: A GET against this URI refreshes the representation of this resource.

___outboundFilter.description: A GET against this URI retrieves the outbound filter chain.

___hostId.description: ID of the port's host. This will be set when binding a port to a host (becoming an exterior port).

___hostInterfacePort.description: A GET against this URI retrieves the interface-binding information of this port.

___deviceId.description: ID of the device (bridge or router) that this port belongs to.

___bgps.description: A GET against this URI retrieves BGP configurations for this port.

___networkLength.description: Prefix length of the network attached to this port (number of fixed network bits).

___inboundFilterId.description: ID of the filter chain to be applied for incoming packets.

___peer.description: A GET against this URI retrieves the peer port resource. Requires a port to be linked to another port.

___vlanId.description: The VLAN ID assigned to this port. On a given bridge, each VLAN ID can be present at most in one interior port.

___id.description: A unique identifier of the resource.

___peerId.description: ID of the peer port that this port is linked to. This will be set when linking a port to another peer (becoming an interior port).

___host.description: The port host's URI. Requires a port to be bound to a host

___interfaceName.description: Interface name of a bound port. This will be set when binding a port to a host (becoming an exterior port).
